tour.name: The Critical Strip
tour.description: The strip 0 < Re(s) < 1 where all non-trivial zeros reside. The Riemann Hypothesis claims they all lie on Re(s) = ½.

tour.name: The Pole
tour.description: The only singularity of ζ(s). A simple pole with residue 1, where the function explodes to infinity.

tour.name: The Origin
tour.description: ζ(0) = −½. This mysterious value connects to the sum 1+2+3+... = −1/12 via analytic continuation.

tour.name: The Basel Problem
tour.description: ζ(2) = π²/6 ≈ 1.645. Euler's 1734 solution stunned the mathematical world.

tour.name: Apéry's Constant
tour.description: ζ(3) ≈ 1.202. Proven irrational by Roger Apéry in 1978, still mysterious today.

tour.name: First Trivial Zero
tour.description: ζ(−2) = 0. Trivial zeros arise from sin(πs/2) in the functional equation. 'Trivial' because their existence is easily proven.

tour.name: Second Trivial Zero
tour.description: ζ(−4) = 0. All negative even integers are zeros—infinitely many

tour.name: Saddle Point (Right)
tour.description: Where ζ'(s) = 0. Saddle points come in symmetric pairs across the critical line.

tour.name: Saddle Point (Left)
tour.description: The mirror image saddle point at Re(s) = 0, symmetric with its partner at Re(s) = 1.

tour.name: Gram Point g₁
tour.description: Where Im(ζ(½+it)) = 0. Gram points bracket zeros and help locate them.

tour.name: The Gateway Zero
tour.description: Found by Riemann in 1859. It confirms the Zeta function's link to the distribution of primes.

tour.name: The Spacing Benchmark
tour.description: Its distance from the first zero (~6.89) began the study of 'spectral gaps' in number theory.

tour.name: The Stability Zero
tour.description: Part of the original set that suggested all non-trivial zeros lie on the Critical Line (Re=1/2).

tour.name: The Chaos Indicator
tour.description: Exhibits the irregular, 'random matrix' behavior typical of complex quantum systems.

tour.name: The Near Twin
tour.description: Part of an unusually tight cluster, demonstrating that zeros do not appear at regular intervals.

tour.name: Hardy's Milestone
tour.description: Confirmed by G.H. Hardy in 1914, proving infinitely many zeros exist on the critical line.

tour.name: The Pre-Computer Limit
tour.description: Marks the boundary of what 19th-century mathematicians could verify through manual calculation.

tour.name: The Repulsion Effect
tour.description: An example of 'level repulsion,' where zeros rarely get too close, similar to energy levels in atoms.

tour.name: The Prime Regulator
tour.description: Higher zeros like this one 'fine-tune' the error term in the Prime Number Theorem.

tour.name: The Gram Point Link
tour.description: Calculated by J.P. Gram (1903), who developed methods to predict zero locations.

tour.name: Functional Equation
tour.description: The symmetry ζ(s) ↔ ζ(1−s) reflects the function across the critical line.
